content.description: Dabble in a bit of wide crack climbing on this one. Pick your poison, the left-leaning hand crack, or the fists and offwidth. Both are moderately enjoyable and would be quite fun if they were, say, 70 feet taller.
content.protection: Gear from 1" to 4", bolted anchor slightly right of cracks, or build your own.
content.location: Obvious "V" just to right of center.

content.description: An easy, un-intimidating introduction to traditional climbing. Climb the highly featured right side of Bee Block face.
content.protection: Gear to four inches. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Farthest right route on the face.

content.description: This route ascends the obvious plumb line up the formation just uphill and left of Bee Block. Positive feet and fun features from bottom to top. Walk off or build a very long, extended top rope anchor.
content.protection: Gear to three inches. No anchors! Build your own or walk off.
content.location: Up the hill and to the left of Bee Block, just about twenty feet.

content.description:
Just relax, breathe, and enjoy the sound of the creek behind you--because this route's over as soon as you get off the ground!

An excellent route for young children, the acrophobic, or a brand new climber.
content.protection: Gear to two inches. Sport anchors.

content.description: This is it--the business, the main event, the proud King line of Bee Block. Screw your courage to the sticking place and venture forth. Climb the steepest (ha ha) portion in the center of the formation.
content.protection: Gear to two inches. Sport anchors.
content.location: Center of the wall, using cracks and face holds.

content.description: Pull big moves on sloping rails on the far right side of the Bee Block.
